qas.question: In which Prussian province did a large Polish population reside?
What was there strong support of in Posen?
What calls were made for the Polish recruits?

answers.text: to desert from the Prussian Army

qas.question: On what date did Bismarkck receive the disturbing report on the Posen situation?
What significant consequence was a result of German-Polish relations?

context: In the Prussian province of <a0_0>Posen<a0_0/>, with a large Polish population, there was strong support for <a1_0>the French<a1_0/> and angry demonstrations at news of Prussian-German victories—a clear manifestation of Polish nationalist feeling. Calls were also made for Polish recruits <a2_0>to desert from the Prussian Army<a2_0/>—though these went mainly unheeded. An alarming report on the Posen situation, sent to Bismarck on <a3_0>16 August 1870<a3_0/>, led to the quartering of reserve troop contingents in the restive province. The Franco-Prussian War thus turned out to be a significant event also in German–Polish relations, marking the beginning of a <a4_0>prolonged period of repressive measures<a4_0/> by the authorities and efforts at Germanisation.
